contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox President | name=Vicente Rocafuerte | image=Vicente Rocafuerte.jpg | order=2nd [[List of heads of state of Ecuador|President of Ecuador]] | term_start=August 8, 1835 | term_end=January 31, 1839 | vicepresident=[[Juan Bernardo León]] | predecessor=[[Juan José Flores]] | successor=[[Juan José Flores]] | order2=2nd [[List of heads of state of Ecuador|Supreme Chief of the State]] | term_start2=June 8. 1835 | term_end2=August 8, 1835 | vicepresident2= | predecessor2= | successor2= | order3=[[Supreme Chief of the Department of Guayas]] | term_start3=September 10. 1834 | term_end3=June 22, 1835 | vicepresident3= | predecessor3= | successor3= | birth_date={{Birth date|1783|5|1|mf=y}} | birth_place=[[Guayaquil]], [[Ecuador]] | death_date={{death date and age|1847|5|16|1783|5|1}} | death_place=[[Lima]], [[Peru]] | spouse=[[Baltasara Calderón]] | occupation= | alma_mater= | party= | religion= |signature=Firma de Vicente Rocafuerte.svg |}} '''Vicente Rocafuerte y Bejarano''' (May 1, 1783 – May 16, 1847) was an influential figure in Ecuadorian politics and [[List of heads of state of Ecuador|President of Ecuador]] from September 10, 1834 to January 31, 1839. He was born into an [[Aristocracy (class)|aristocrat]]ic family in [[Guayaquil]], [[Ecuador]], and as a youth, was sent to [[Madrid]] to finish his education. He returned to Ecuador in 1807, and committed himself to freeing his land, first from [[Viceroyalty of New Granada|Spanish]] rule, and later from the [[Republic of Gran Colombia]]. After Ecuadorian independence, Rocafuerte was elected a member of the [[National Congress of Ecuador|National Congress]] for [[Pichincha Province]]. He led the opposition to President [[Juan José Flores]], who exiled him to [[Peru]]. Rocafuerte returned, and on September 20, 1833, became [[Governor]] of [[Guayas Province]]. He revolted against Flores, but was defeated and imprisoned. Because of the respect he was held in by his many supporters, Rocafuerte negotiated a settlement with Flores, and was released from prison. The settlement allowed Flores to finish his term in office, and promised Rocafuerte would become president afterwards, with Flores to head the army. During his presidency, Rocafuerte passed a new constitution in 1835, and gave greater protection to [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native Americans]] in Ecuador. In 1839, after Rocafuerte had left office, Flores was again elected president, and for some time there were no difficulties between the two men. However, after electoral irregularities in 1843, Flores annulled the 1835 constitution and passed a new one, called by Rocafuerte 'The Letter of Slavery'. When Flores took up a third term as president in 1843, Rocafuerte left Ecuador in protest. After a short rebellion, Rocafuerte and [[Vicente Ramón Roca]] overthrew Flores on March 6, 1845, and Roca became president of Ecuador later that year. Under [[Vicente Ramón Roca]]'s presidency, Rocafuerte was appointed as special representative to various [[South American]] countries.
